```{r data generation, echo = FALSE, results = "hide"}
types = c("A","B","C","D")
while(T){
  mus = sample(60:150,4)
  sigs = sample(4:15,4)
  ps = round(runif(4,0.02,0.98),4)
  zs = round(qnorm(ps),2)
  xs = signif(mus+zs*sigs,4)
  if(sort(zs)==sort(unique(zs)) 
     & sum(zs>0)>1 
     & sum(zs>0)<4 
     & zs[zs==max(zs)]!=zs[xs==max(xs)]){
    break
  }
}
```

Question
========

(10 points)

A farm produces 4 types of fruit: $A$, $B$, $C$, and $D$. The fruits' masses follow normal distributions, with parameters dependent on the type of fruit.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}\hline
Type of fruit & Mean mass (g) & Standard deviation of mass (g) \\ \hline
$A$ & `r mus[1]` & `r sigs[1]` \\
$B$ & `r mus[2]` & `r sigs[2]` \\
$C$ & `r mus[3]` & `r sigs[3]` \\
$D$ & `r mus[4]` & `r sigs[4]` \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

One specimen of each type is weighed. The results are shown below.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}\hline
Type of fruit & Mass of specimen (g) \\ \hline
$A$ & `r xs[1]` \\
$B$ & `r xs[2]` \\
$C$ & `r xs[3]` \\
$D$ & `r xs[4]` \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

Which specimen is the most unusually large (relative to others of its type)?

Solution
========

We compare the $z$-scores. The largest $z$-score corresponds to the specimen that is most unusually large.

\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}\hline
Type of fruit & formula &  $z$-score \\ \hline
$A$ & $z=\frac{`r xs[1]`-`r mus[1]`}{`r sigs[1]`}$ &`r zs[1]` \\
$B$ & $z=\frac{`r xs[2]`-`r mus[2]`}{`r sigs[2]`}$ &`r zs[2]` \\
$C$ & $z=\frac{`r xs[3]`-`r mus[3]`}{`r sigs[3]`}$ &`r zs[3]` \\
$D$ & $z=\frac{`r xs[4]`-`r mus[4]`}{`r sigs[4]`}$ &`r zs[4]` \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
\end{center}

Thus, the specimen of type $`r types[zs==max(zs)]`$ is the most unusually large.
